Award.AwardTitle: New Frontiers of Direct Laser Acceleration in Megatesla Magnetic Fields
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines analytically and using computer simulations a novel regime in which an unprecedented magnetic field, generated in a laser-irradiated solid density target, enhances acceleration of electrons and, as a result, enables emission of copious very energetic photons. Light-matter interactions at ultra-high intensities are the next frontier of the advanced accelerator research with the potential to enable development of novel accelerators and x-ray sources. This regime has the potential to disrupt existing paradigms and advance accelerator science at a fundamental level. The prospect of generating copious quantities of energetic photons in laser-target interactions is of particular interest due to its many possible applications, including photo-nuclear spectroscopy, radiation therapy, and radio surgery. The study is also of fundamental relevance to astrophysics, as it can pave the way to creation of matter and antimatter from light, thus providing valuable insights into the inner workings of the universe. The project will provide essential student training in accelerator science, plasma physics and high performance computing.

The novelty of the regime investigated by this project is that the extreme magnetic field couples three key aspects of laser-plasma interactions at high intensities: relativistic transparency, direct laser acceleration, and synchrotron photon emission. The key questions investigated by the project cover fundamental aspects of electron acceleration in Megatesla-level magnetic fields, including energy scaling with plasma and laser pulse parameters, and the mechanism underpinning generation of such a strong laser-driven magnetic field in a plasma. The project specifically examines the interplay between electron acceleration and photon emission. This interplay is the key feature of this regime, because, while the acceleration enhances the photon emission, the photon emission itself has a strong feedback on the microscopic electron motion. In addition to the synchrotron emission, the project also addresses the role of bremsstrahlung. The bremsstrahlung emission can become relevant due to high plasma density, but the presence of the Megatesla magnetic field can have a profound mitigating effect, suppressing photon emission.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Using three-dimensional numerical simulations we have explored a novel regime where a Megatesla-level magnetic field is generated inside a dense laser-irradiated target at extremely high, but experimentally accessible laser intensities. Such fields are prohibitively strong to be generated using conventional methods in laboratory conditions. We found that the strong magnetic field enables the laser to efficiently create a population of very energetic electrons after propagating just tens on microns into the target, with electron energies reaching the GeV level (the electron energy that is over a thousand times higher than the rest energy). We also found that electron deflections by the magnetic field lead to emission of very energetic photons. The emission process has been optimized at a fixed laser intensity and we found that the conversion efficiency of the laser energy into energetic photons can be increased by increasing the power of the irradiating laser up to 4 PW while using a structured target with a pre-filled channel. This approach promises an unprecedented laser energy conversion efficiency of 1.5% into a collimated beam of multi-MeV photons, with over 1012 photons in total. One application that directly benefits from such an efficient photon source is the electron-positron pair production from light alone. This process is a basic prediction of quantum electrodynamics relating energy to matter, but it is yet to be observed. We have investigated two different schemes for photon-photon collisions and found that hundreds of thousands of pairs can be produced using two 4 PW lasers. This prediction indicates that a corresponding experiment is feasible at the newly constructed multi-PW, multi-beam 10 PW laser facility called ELI-NP. 

 

This project has provided training to three students (one graduate and two undergraduate students) and to one postdoctoral scholar, thus preparing future workforce with expert knowledge of high-intensity light-matter interactions. Some scientific results of the project are easily accessible even at an undergraduate level, so they have been presented at two summer schools, incorporated into summer internship projects, and even taught as a part of a undergraduate technical elective at UC San Diego focused on nuclear energy.
